query: Investigate Ali Khaledi Nasab an Irani AI Researcher working for Amazon

Check Iranian academic publication databases for research papers or academic profiles

task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for current role and professional details of Ali Khaledi Nasab at Amazon
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon's Rufus division. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctorate, he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders. In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments. Following the startup's closure in 2022 due to funding challenges, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he moved to Amazon's Rufus division to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has contributed to various research projects, including studying the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons and exploring methods to depolarize echo chambers in social networks. He has also been involved in editing the Brain Development section of the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for significant contributions in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional work, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has shared his experiences and insights through writing, including a piece in Science Magazine titled "I almost sold a kidney to pursue my PhD," reflecting on the challenges faced by international students in funding their education. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Ali Khaledi, Ph. D.
Ali Khaledi, Ph. D.

task_2.query_used: Check Iranian academic publication databases for research papers or academic profiles
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research focuses on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. He has presented his work at various academic venues, including a colloquium at the College of Wooster in October 2017, where he discussed "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his research, Khaledi Nasab has been active in addressing challenges faced by international students. In April 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine, where he shared his experiences and the difficulties encountered by international students in the United States during that period. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his academic affiliations, Khaledi Nasab has been associated with Ohio University, where he pursued his doctoral studies in Physics and Astronomy. He has also been recognized by the American Physical Society, receiving a 2019 Student Travel Award to attend the APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

While specific information about his current position is limited, his previous roles include serving as a senior researcher at the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, a profile on exaly.com indicates that Khaledi Nasab has been affiliated with the University of Tabriz, with a notable number of publications and citations. ([exaly.com](https://exaly.com/author/5034433/ali-khaledi-nasab?utm_source=openai))

However, a search of the Scientific Information Database (SID) did not yield any publications authored by Ali Khaledi Nasab, suggesting that his work may not be indexed in this particular database. ([en.irandoc.ac.ir](https://en.irandoc.ac.ir/taxonomy/term/3031?utm_source=openai))

task_3.query_used: Search Iranian news archives and technology publications for mentions of Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data: Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist who has contributed to the field of dynamical systems. In February 2018, he presented a seminar titled "Collective Dynamics of Random Tree Networks of Excitable Elements" at Ohio University. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/topics/ali-khaledi/?utm_source=openai)) This work focused on understanding the collective behavior of networks composed of excitable elements, which has applications in various scientific disciplines.

task_4.query_used: Investigate Google Scholar for AI research publications or citations under this name
task_4.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with a diverse background in physics, neuroscience, and machine learning. His work encompasses areas such as nonlinear dynamics, computational neuroscience, and artificial intelligence. He has been affiliated with institutions like Ohio University and the University of Tabriz.

In 2017, as a graduate student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, Khaledi-Nasab presented a colloquium titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements" at the College of Wooster. This research focused on the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to sensory neurons like cat muscle spindles. The study suggested mechanisms for tuning the activity of central elements in these networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In 2019, he received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS meeting in Boston. There, he presented a paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons," further contributing to the understanding of information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

Khaledi-Nasab has also co-authored several publications in the field of machine learning and artificial intelligence. Notably, he has worked on the development of ZnO nanoparticles using potato extract as a reducing agent and stabilizer, as well as on the optical properties of InAs/GaAs quantum dots. His research has been cited numerous times, reflecting his contributions to these areas. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has been involved in studies related to the desynchronization effects of coordinated reset stimulation in neuronal networks, aiming to improve the understanding of neural dynamics and potential therapeutic applications. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10013062/?utm_source=openai))

Overall, Ali Khaledi-Nasab's work spans multiple disciplines, contributing to advancements in both theoretical and applied aspects of physics, neuroscience, and artificial intelligence.

Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_5.query_used: Check ResearchGate or similar academic networking platforms for professional research profile
task_5.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist specializing in the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly focusing on sensory neurons with branched myelinated terminals. His doctoral research at Ohio University, supervised by Professor Alexander Neiman, involved theoretical and computational studies to understand mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in these neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS annual meeting in Boston, where he presented his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

He has also contributed to discussions on the experiences of international students in the United States, sharing his personal challenges and perspectives in a column titled "Standing up to fear" published in *Science* magazine. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi Nasab has authored several publications on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks and the role of synaptic plasticity in brain development. His work has been featured in various academic journals and platforms, reflecting his ongoing contributions to the field. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/figure/The-classifications-of-neurons-based-on-the-branches-that-originate-from-the-cell-body_fig1_334373044?utm_source=openai), [researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Schematic-representation-of-neuroplasticity-at-different-levels-A-Synaptic-plasticity_fig1_365439270?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_6.query_used: Search Iranian professional registry databases for technology or AI professional credentials
task_6.data: Ali Khaledi Nasab is an Iranian physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. He earned his Ph.D. in physics from Ohio University, where he conducted research on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks. After completing his Ph.D., he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders. In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup, before joining Amazon in 2022 as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he became an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University. His research interests encompass nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In 2024, he transitioned to Amazon Rufus to work on the company's latest generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Before joining Amazon, Dr. Khaledi Nasab earned his Ph.D. and conducted postdoctoral research at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery. He also worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional work, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has been active in academia, serving as an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University. He has also contributed to the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi Nasab's research interests include machine learning, artificial intelligence, networks, computational neuroscience, and nonlinear dynamics. He has published several papers in these areas, reflecting his expertise and contributions to the field. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 13, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist originally from Iran, currently working at Amazon's Rufus division. His background includes research in dynamical systems, computational neuroscience, and artificial intelligence, with affiliations to institutions like Stanford University and Ohio University. There is no information to suggest any immediate risks.

### Key Intelligence by Category

**1. Career / Employment**

*   Currently works as a physicist and AI scientist at Amazon's Rufus division.
*   Previously worked at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on developing stimulation techniques for treating neurological disorders.
*   Doctoral research at Ohio University, supervised by Professor Alexander Neiman.

**2. Financial / Corporate Ties**

*   Currently employed by Amazon. No other financial or corporate ties are mentioned.

**3. Legal / Regulatory Issues**

*   No legal or regulatory issues are mentioned.

**4. Academic / Public Presence**

*   Ph.D. from Ohio University.
*   Presented a colloquium at the College of Wooster in October 2017 on "Emergent Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks."
*   Presented a seminar at Ohio University in February 2018 titled "Collective Dynamics of Random Tree Networks of Excitable Elements."
*   Received an APS travel award to attend a conference.
*   Research focuses on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons.

**5. Online / Social Media**

*   Has a personal website: alikhaledi.com.
*   Published a document titled "Standing up to fear" on Academia.edu.

**6. Additional Observations**

*   Originally from Iran, moved to the United States in 2014.
*   Research interests span physics, neuroscience, and machine learning.

### Risk Score

Low. Ali Khaledi Nasab appears to be a researcher and scientist with a solid academic background and professional affiliations. There is no information suggesting any reputational or security risks.

Missing detail: His article 'I almost sold a kidney to pursue my PhD' in Science Magazine is not mentioned

judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 13, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist originally from Iran, currently working at Amazon's Rufus division¹. His background includes research in dynamical systems, computational neuroscience, and artificial intelligence, with affiliations to institutions like Stanford University and Ohio University. There is no information to suggest any immediate risks.

### Key Intelligence by Category

**1. Career / Employment**

*   Currently works as a physicist and AI scientist at Amazon's Rufus division (joined 2024)¹
*   Previously worked at Amazon AWS network capacity team as a research scientist (2022-2024)¹
*   Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments (2021-2022, company closed due to funding challenges)¹
*   Previously worked at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on developing stimulation techniques for treating neurological disorders¹
*   Became an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University in 2024⁶
*   Previously served as a senior researcher at the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States²
*   Doctoral research at Ohio University, supervised by Professor Alexander Neiman⁵

**2. Financial / Corporate Ties**

*   Currently employed by Amazon. No other financial or corporate ties are mentioned.

**3. Legal / Regulatory Issues**

*   No legal or regulatory issues are mentioned.

**4. Academic / Public Presence**

*   Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University⁵
*   Presented a colloquium at the College of Wooster in October 2017 on "Emergent Dynamics of Excitable Tree Networks"²⁴
*   Presented a seminar at Ohio University in February 2018 titled "Collective Dynamics of Random Tree Networks of Excitable Elements"³
*   Received an APS Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award to attend a conference⁴⁵
*   Research focuses on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies⁴⁵
*   Co-authored publications on ZnO nanoparticles using potato extract and optical properties of InAs/GaAs quantum dots⁴
*   Contributed to editing the Brain Development section of the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award¹
*   Involved in studies on desynchronization effects of coordinated reset stimulation in neuronal networks⁴
*   Research interests span nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences⁶

**5. Online / Social Media**

*   Has a personal website: alikhaledi.com¹⁶
*   Published a document titled "Standing up to fear" on Academia.edu in April 2017, addressing challenges faced by international students²⁵
*   Authored an article "I almost sold a kidney to pursue my PhD" in Science Magazine, reflecting on funding challenges for international students¹

**6. Additional Observations**

*   Originally from Iran, moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D.¹
*   Research interests span physics, neuroscience, and machine learning
*   Has been affiliated with the University of Tabriz according to some profiles²

### Risk Score

Low. Ali Khaledi Nasab appears to be a legitimate researcher and scientist with a solid academic background and professional affiliations at reputable institutions. There is no information suggesting any reputational or security risks.

### Citations
¹ alikhaledi.com (Task 1, Task 6)
² ohio-forum.com, academia.edu, loop.frontiersin.org, exaly.com (Task 2)
³ ohio-forum.com (Task 3)
⁴ ohio-forum.com, scholar.google.com, pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov (Task 4)
⁵ ohio-forum.com, academia.edu, researchgate.net (Task 5)
⁶ alikhaledi.com (Task 6)

In 2024, he became an adjunct professor of physics at Ohio University. His research interests encompass nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Ali Khaledi, Ph. D.
